user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_SHA256_init:
```c
void
MHD_SHA256_init (struct Sha256Ctx *ctx)
{
  /* Initial hash values, see FIPS PUB 180-4 paragraph 5.3.3 */
  /* First thirty-two bits of the fractional parts of the square
   * roots of the first eight prime numbers: 2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13,
   * 17, 19." */
  ctx->H[0] = UINT32_C (0x6a09e667);
  ctx->H[1] = UINT32_C (0xbb67ae85);
  ctx->H[2] = UINT32_C (0x3c6ef372);
  ctx->H[3] = UINT32_C (0xa54ff53a);
  ctx->H[4] = UINT32_C (0x510e527f);
  ctx->H[5] = UINT32_C (0x9b05688c);
  ctx->H[6] = UINT32_C (0x1f83d9ab);
  ctx->H[7] = UINT32_C (0x5be0cd19);

  /* Initialise number of bytes. */
  ctx->count = 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function MHD_SHA256_init:
struct Sha256Ctx
{
  uint32_t H[SHA256_DIGEST_SIZE_WORDS];     /**< Intermediate hash value / digest at end of calculation */
  uint32_t buffer[SHA256_BLOCK_SIZE_WORDS]; /**< SHA256 input data buffer */
  uint64_t count;                           /**< number of bytes, mod 2^64 */
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No other pointer declarations or pointer parameters appear in the provided code; the struct Sha256Ctx contains only array and scalar members (uint32_t arrays and a uint64_t), not pointer members. The body contains direct assignments to ctx->H[...] and ctx->count, indicating the function modifies the context object; therefore there are no additional pointer usages in this fragment that could be const-qualified. Other parts of the code do not present pointer-to-non-const occurrences to be investigated for Rule 8.13.
